review_preview: It is my husbands and I first night in Madrid and the third week of travelling. Although we were tired from a day of travel we wanted to try some local cuisine and didn’t want to walk long looking for a restaurant.What a delight...
review_full: It is my husbands and I first night in Madrid and the third week of travelling. Although we were tired from a day of travel we wanted to try some local cuisine and didn’t want to walk long looking for a restaurant. What a delight it was to find Morgana just down the street from where were staying. From the moment we walked in the staff was welcoming and was able to seat us in spite of not having a reservation. The food was an amazing culinary invention of Asian and Galatian cuisine. My husband had a Spanish omelette, that was cooked to perfection with a moist centre with layers of flavour. I had the grilled octopus covered with Galatian cheese on a bed of kimchi infused potatoes. Every mouthful was an explosion of flavour. Both meals were paired with the perfect selection of wines recommended by our servers the meal ended with a melt in your mouth cheese cake We enjoyed ourselves so much that we intend to have another meal at Morgana’s before we leave this beautiful city.

Moratin was the highest rated restaurant nearby so we walked there -- and weren't disappointed. As the many reviews say, this is a small, delightful place with excellent food and friendly, helpful service. The wine list is extensive, although we had a glass of white and tinto recommended by our lovely waitress (whose English was impeccable). Both wines were excellent and reasonably priced. We shared a mushroom in cauliflower purée appetizer and the veal cannelloni main course. Both were exquisite. We suspect the restaurant is equally good for dinner.

Her sister is the chef, and makes sure to come out, not only to say hi and check on the food, but to learn about you. Once again, we never felt so comfortable in a resturant.  This place had excellent food with service straight from the heart. Couldn't have asked for a better last dinner in Madrid.  THANK YOU BOTH♡

title_review: An amazing experience in Algarabia with Isabel and Pilar
review_preview: My sister and I, with our respective husbands, dined at Algarabia this week following some really good reviews on Trip Advisor - we were not disappointed.  Isabel greeted us in an extremely warm and friendly manner and made us feel very at home from the...
review_full: My sister and I, with our respective husbands, dined at Algarabia this week following some really good reviews on Trip Advisor - we were not disappointed. Isabel greeted us in an extremely warm and friendly manner and made us feel very at home from the outset. She made menu suggestions and looked after us very attentively. The food was excellent - we had croquetas to start and sardinas; main courses were bacalao in tomato sauce which was very tasty, pork which was excellent and tuna meat balls. I had the squid stew which was ok but aesthetically did not wow - the only very small issue with what was a highly entertaining evening. Pilar, the head chef came out from the kitchen and greeted us after the main course, like her sister, she was extremely friendly and very welcoming. We all had a magnificent time and would recommend a visit. We will definitely be going back on our next visit to Madrid! Many thanks to Isabel and Pilar for a wonderful evening!!

title_review: Don’t Walk by this Hidden Gem
review_preview: Restaurants Morgana is a hidden gem of the highest standard. The passion of the owner and the team is infectious and the quality and delivery of food exceeds expectations. We found this on trip advisor as it was close to the hotel and there was...
review_full: Restaurants Morgana is a hidden gem of the highest standard.  The passion of the owner and the team is infectious and the quality and delivery of food exceeds expectations.  We found this on trip advisor as it was close to the hotel and there was only one spot left late Sunday night and we are glad we took it.  We had very different dishes so that we could share, from the squid, croquettes, mussels and tuna all perfectly served with interesting twists. The food would grace the table at any top restaurant in any city in the world.  Don’t miss this gem.

review_preview: The day had arrived to go to this wonderful restaurant for the first time, 5 hours before our reservation I fell and hurt my ankle, on returning to the UK I have since discovered it is broken!! But that didn't stop us getting a taxi...
review_full: The day had arrived to go to this wonderful restaurant for the first time, 5 hours before our reservation I fell and hurt my ankle, on returning to the UK I have since discovered it is broken!! But that didn't stop us getting a taxi here for our long awaited meal.... First of all from the outside it looks a very modern, chic place but on entering you feel like you have entered the home of these two delightful ladies... You are essentially in their front room! Charming, pretty, quaint, are words I would describe. We ordered a bottle of the house Rioja, and were told to wait precisely two minutes before tasting it! We obeyed and it was delicious... House croquettes, slow cooked oxtail, pork fillet, then a wonderful toffee apple dessert... Every bit as good as the last. Being asked all the time if we liked and not having to nod politely saying we did, because we really did enjoy every mouthful. Meeting the chef at the end of the evening and thanking her for all the wonderful food was a pleasure... Also being taken to the loo because of my bad foot by both the sisters at different parts of the evening was really above and beyond... My lovely ladies we will return soon, Thank you Caroline & Jason

review_preview: My wife and I had a long weekend in Madrid a few weeks ago. One of the most important aspects of a weekend or holiday for us is the restaurants, good food, ambience, efficient and friendly staff and not costing an arm and a leg....
review_full: My wife and I had a long weekend in Madrid a few weeks ago. One of the most important aspects of a weekend or holiday for us is the restaurants, good food, ambience, efficient and friendly staff and not costing an arm and a leg.  We booked three restaurants from Trip advisor for the three nights we were in Madrid. The best with out a doubt was Algarabia. The restaurant had a delightful ambiance, the food was excellent (my wife had a fantastic pork dish and I had rabbit in a Bolognese sauce … very tasty). But the most endearing aspect of the restaurant was the sisters Pilar and Isabel, who were the owners, cook and waitress. After our meal we spent some time talking and joking with them it was a delightful evening. If you get a chance have an evening with Pilar and Isabel in their Restaurant I can assure you . . . . you will not be disappointed.

review_preview: What a charming little place!  This restaurant is owned by two sisters who take great pride in their delicious food.  One sister is the chef, and the other is in front of the house taking wonderful care of the diners.  They don't normally open until...
review_full: What a charming little place! This restaurant is owned by two sisters who take great pride in their delicious food. One sister is the chef, and the other is in front of the house taking wonderful care of the diners. They don't normally open until 9:30 p.m., but they graciously gave us a 9:00 p.m. reservation time to cater to our American earlier eating habits. Our meal began with a wonderful little gazpacho and a pate courtesy of the restaurant. We had fresh pasta with mushrooms and bacon and pork tenderloin with caramelized onions, and croquetas with red shrimp - all recommended. They were so friendly and anxious to please, and the chef came out to chat with us when she had a break in the kitchen. The ambiance was so cheery and inviting also. Make reservations because there is limited seating, and you won't be disappointed.

title_review: Intimate atmosphere, great food, even better hosts!
review_preview: We came here on a friday night.  At 10:30pm there were only two other tables occupied.  Apparently folks prefer to dine on terraces during this time of the year.  Lucky for us because we didn't need a reservation.  This restaurant is owned by two sisters...
review_full: We came here on a friday night. At 10:30pm there were only two other tables occupied. Apparently folks prefer to dine on terraces during this time of the year. Lucky for us because we didn't need a reservation. This restaurant is owned by two sisters who are just absolutely, wonderful women. They made us feel so welcomed (which is hard to come by in Madrid)! One sister runs the front while the other sister is the chef. I'm so glad we had the opportunity to experience this wonderful restaurant. The sister running the front was very helpful when it came down to ordering and helping us navigate through the menu. The menu isn't overwhelming at all. I would like to think that if I opened a quaint restaurant someday, that it would be something like this. You can tell that the dishes are tailored to what the Sister Chef feels is best for the season. They have a friend at a winery who makes a blend just for them, so therefore, the "house" wine is excellent, worthy of a store shelf. Another friend bakes the bread. The Sister in the Front checked on us several times to chat with us and make sure we were ok, but totally in a non-obtrusive way. It was the perfect balance of attentiveness and privacy. Once we were finished, the Sister Chef came to our table to get our opinions on everything. I really enjoyed the whole experience so much. It will definitely be a dining experience to remember. I loved seeing the two sisters interact. It made me wonder how my mom and one of her six sisters would be if they had a restaurant! These two ladies made us feel as though we were visiting one of our Aunts who prepared a wonderful welcome home meal for us. They even took the time to bring us a booklet showing us what was available in the area to view, culturally. We really appreciated that and hope to check the events out. They genuinely cared about the rest of our trip. Back to the food....The pork was perfectly cooked, moist, and full of flavor. The ox tails were tender and rich. Also, our appetizer was delicious, as well as the small appetizer that was complements of the house. Overall, the food and ambiance can't be beat for this price point. I highly suggest dining here. You cannot get a personal touch along with 5 star food at many places in the world. Don't pass this by!

review_preview: We happened across this restaurant based on a recommendation from a Devour tapas tour guide’s personal recs.  We didn’t have reservations, but tried our luck anyway and showed up right when it opened at 1:30.  They were booked solid for the next 4 days, but...
review_full: We happened across this restaurant based on a recommendation from a Devour tapas tour guide’s personal recs. We didn’t have reservations, but tried our luck anyway and showed up right when it opened at 1:30. They were booked solid for the next 4 days, but the waiter must have seen the desperate look on my face, so he took pity and “squeezed” us in…. Mindful of the accommodation, we at least tried to promise we’d be quick and would be in and out before the table was spoken for at 3PM… The waiter quickly corrected our way of thinking immediately and told us to just relax and enjoy the food. (We literally spent all afternoon here, following orders)  I’m a fairly well traveled foody, very much guided by my stomach, and generally spare no expense whatsoever on food and wine. It’s a priority. This accidental lunch we had ranks among the best meals I’ve ever had, ever.  The food wasn’t covered up in mystery cream sauces and/or bacon infused foam--we ordered mostly vegetables. It was simple, unpretentious, and just perfect. Our starter was a hot tomato soup—hearty and really vibrant. Next: artichokes, Leeks, Pulpo and then Steak Tartare. We had a cheese cake and sorbet respectively for dessert. Each dish was paired with a really gorgeous glass of sherry, wine or port (with dessert). I highly recommend turning over discretion on both the food and wine pairings to the wait staff—they did an amazing job.  Our two favorite dishes were the leeks and the artichoke hearts. I’ve never met an artichoke I didn’t like, but these were just perfect and unlike anything I’ve ever tried before in California—tender and lightly seasoned with a simple sauce and some sort of season salt/bullion. The leeks were ridiculous—again, not fussed with much, but just lightly seasoned and perfectly cooked. The same theme was present in the lemon basil sorbet –neither overly acidic or sweet—just darn good.  The service at this tiny little restaurant was impeccable. Like all the other tourists everywhere else, we were probably underdressed, but the atmosphere is casual and there’s not a lick of pretentiousness to the place at all. This place is just great! I highly recommend it. It’s a 7 out of 5 really.

title_review: 3rd time and still wonderful - a real gem in Madrid
review_preview: Was in Madrid again and made sure to go back to the Vinoteca Moratin again. Invited a colleague to join. As always, we were blown away by the charm, friendliness and quality of the food. This was my 3rd time there in the last two...
review_full: Was in Madrid again and made sure to go back to the Vinoteca Moratin again. Invited a colleague to join. As always, we were blown away by the charm, friendliness and quality of the food. This was my 3rd time there in the last two years and it was just as good as always (in fact I was pleased to see that half the restaurant was taken by locals and not tourists.) The menu is not extensive but everything is prepared with care. There are half portions available for many of the dishes so between the two of us we could try four different things. Everything is nicely seasoned, even the half portions are not small. They have a very nice wine selection and the prices are great. Not only that, they are amazingly helpful on the wine, going so far as to steer us to a less expensive bottle that they felt would go better with the meal as well as letting us know that if we didn't like it, they would take it back as they could simply offer it by the glass then. The waiter went so far as to say that they had 25 wines by the glass and they didn't mind having 26. No need to return it though. My colleague who lives in Madrid had recalled several wines that we had the previous time that she was unable to find in any store and she asked the waiter about it an he was extraordinarily helpful in letting us know exactly where to go and what to ask for. The interior is very cozy with no more than 10ish tables. Tables are spaced nicely so you don't feel like you are sitting on top of each other. Décor is attractive. The best thing is the value - we had aperitifs, a bottle of good wine, four half portions, dessert wine and coffee and spent only 77 Euros for the two of us! I've eaten in many Michelin starred restaurants around the world where the cost is easily 5x or more and although they may be more delicate or complex, this place never ceases to amaze me for the overall quality, friendliness and value.

review_preview: My husband and I ate here in September, 2016.  The restaurant is a bit difficult to find, even for the taxi driver, but with the GPS they found it.  The charm of this restaurant is derived from the two sisters who run it.  Isabel takes...
review_full: My husband and I ate here in September, 2016. The restaurant is a bit difficult to find, even for the taxi driver, but with the GPS they found it. The charm of this restaurant is derived from the two sisters who run it. Isabel takes your orders and makes suggestions, and Pilar is the cook. Isabel also likes to talk about where you are from and travel information. That enhances the evening. We first had ensalada de pulpo (octopus salad) which was delicious. We then shared the rabo de toro (bull tail) which was very tasty. Finally we shared the Chumarro which is a grilled portion of Iberian pig. That was also tasty. We had the house Rioja with dinner. It was very good. The wine list is hand written on little cards which are glued into an old notebook. A certain charm to that as well. At the end of the evening, since we were unfamiliar with the neighborhood, Isabel was quite kind and walked us two blocks to where taxis were waiting. All in all a very nice evening with good food and charming hosts.

review_preview: We visited Algarabia twice in late September during a tour of Spain and simply loved it.  This small charming restaurant is run by two delightful ladies from Rioja. Isabel looks after the diners while her sister Pilar cooks. Each guest is treated like a member...
review_full: We visited Algarabia twice in late September during a tour of Spain and simply loved it.  This small charming restaurant is run by two delightful ladies from Rioja. Isabel looks after the diners while her sister Pilar cooks. Each guest is treated like a member of the family.   Among the highlights was the wonderful slow-cooked oxtail. Take Isabel’s advice and treat this as finger food: pick the bone up to make the most of the meat. Other memorable dishes included a pork solomillo with soft slow-cooked caramelised onions (the onions are cooked for 2 hours, Pilar tells us) and an octopus salad. We tried the house red wine on our first night and the house white on the second; both were excellent. If you are looking for laminated tourist menus with photographs, or fast food, this isn’t the place for you. If, on the other hand, you prefer delicious Riojan cuisine with the warmest welcome in Madrid, you will love the Algarabia. Thank you, ladies, for your tremendous food and for your warm hospitality. We hope we can return to Madrid and visit Algarabia again.

review_preview: We enjoyed a fabulous meal here when we were in Madrid last month.  I was excited to meet a friend whose blog I have been following for a few years. She invited us to see the Realistas en Madrid exhibit at the Thyssen museum so...
review_full: We enjoyed a fabulous meal here when we were in Madrid last month. I was excited to meet a friend whose blog I have been following for a few years. She invited us to see the Realistas en Madrid exhibit at the Thyssen museum so we met there. Afterwards she gave us a tour of the Las Letras barrio and then we came here for our 2:00 reservation, my friend's recommendation. First off, you must have a reservation. The restaurant is small and very popular so you’ll be disappointed if you arrive without a reservation. The food, service and ambiance were most excellent!! We started with the artichokes and leeks appetizers, both quite delicious. I’m not a big artichoke fan, but these were just wonderful! My friend recommended the chicken and mentioned that the recipe was from the owner’s grandmother. It was accompanied by potatoes and was exquisite! Juicy and very tasty. My husband had the octopus and he appeared to be in heaven and said it was the best food he’d had in Spain. I highly recommend this restaurant. You won’t be disappointed!

review_full: I happen to live in the neighbourhood,buy rarely eat here. This area is just too touristy, and this is not good for quality. However, there are a few exceptions. Perlora, A Casa do Bacalao Portugués, La Cabaña Argentina, for example, And more recently, Vinoteca Moratin. A great place. No wonder it is difficult to find a table even during weekdays (and in spite of the crisis that Spain is still suffering). Nice food. Probably the best steak tartar I ever head. Great service. Great atmosphere. And great pricing. This is an example of how creative and hardworking people can make a restaurant a success in spite of the crisis and in spite of being placed on a sidestreet. Although just two minutes from Huertas and five minutes from the Prado museuim.

title_review: Great Food in a cosy setting
review_preview: We walked in without a booking and very very lucky to get a table and the place was booked out. The front is a small area with bar chairs and in the back the room opens up to seat another 8 or so tablesThe...
review_full: We walked in without a booking and very very lucky to get a table and the place was booked out. The front is a small area with bar chairs and in the back the room opens up to seat another 8 or so tables The service as impeccable and the food wonderfully executed. The staff were very helpful with recommending the wine as were were not familiar with Spanish wine. We had croquettes to start with and they were melt in your mouth delicious. I had the oxtail stew which was very tender with beautiful flavours and my partner had the grilled sole. The fish was a whole fish and presented whole before the bones removed. It was done with such precision and skill that when presented on the plate it look great. The fish was very well cooked and my partner throughly enjoyed it. We would return again to dine in this beautifully cosy restaurant

review_preview: It was my last night in Madrid on a Monday night and I decided to try this restaurant out after reading the excellent reviews on TripAdvisor. It was tough to find though I luckily came across it. The food was great and the sisters (Isabel...
review_full: It was my last night in Madrid on a Monday night and I decided to try this restaurant out after reading the excellent reviews on TripAdvisor. It was tough to find though I luckily came across it. The food was great and the sisters (Isabel & Pillar) who own the restaurant (one is the hostess; the other is the chef) are so friendly that you are treated like family. It was like dining at home, as the atmosphere was peaceful and relaxing. Even after the meal, Pillar came out and asked us how everything was and chatted with a bunch of us after our meal. You can't ask for better service. The food was magnificent and well prepared! I ordered the cod because I love seafood, and also had some very good Vermouth suggested by the Isabel. I'd definitely recommend this gem for anyone visiting Madrid, as it's a home away from home, which you hardly get to experience in a large city! Thankyou both Isabel and Pillar for a memorable and enjoyable evening!

title_review: Simple food with complex sauces, stonkingly good value and service.
review_preview: Having selected and booked (do book) this restaurant based on TA recommendations, my expectations were pretty high. But from the minute we walked into this small vinoteca we were looked after in a completely open and down the earth way. The waiter, who was probably...
review_full: Having selected and booked (do book) this restaurant based on TA recommendations, my expectations were pretty high. But from the minute we walked into this small vinoteca we were looked after in a completely open and down the earth way. The waiter, who was probably also part time owner and/or chef, took the time to apologize for his bad english before describing the entire menu in fast and fluent english... he claims he can only speak English about his menus :) He also helped us to order just the right amount of food, halving some of the portions where necessary so that we could explore more dishes.  It's not really Tapas, but you can approach it like that, which is what we did. The menu is short though, so perhaps not a great place for fussy eaters. As all the other reviews say, the potatoes (not ordered, almost an amuse bouche), the artichokes, and the leeks are all amazing. Simply cooked through a sous vide style (from what we could understand), but well prepared and served with amazing seasoning, from complex and rich sauces, smokey paprika, to a little crunch of sea salt. The beef tartare was fantastic, and served with a very spicy Peruvian hot sauce which we could add to taste. The veal cheek cannelloni was also rich yet delicate with a kind of fluffy béchamel on top. They also helped us match a couple of nice local whites wines. All the staff were pros, with fresh dishes and cutlery between dishes, fresh glasses for each wine, and all able to answer questions about the food. But my biggest surprise was the bill at the end of the night. Only 55 euros total for two people including five *fantastic* dishes (between us) and a couple of glasses of palatable wine each. Wow! If I lived near by I'd be making a standing reservation for Friday nights!

review_full: My husband and I went by the restaurant around 9pm on a Tuesday without a reservation. It was our last night in Madrid and were lucky that there was one table available. It's a small cozy restaurant but there is enough space between tables to make it comfortable for a romantic dinner. Marcos explained every dish in detail. They gave us potatoes with paprika as a starter. Then we ordered the soup of the day which was a fresh tomatoes soup (without cream), you can taste the freshness of the tomatoes and ingredients. Then we had the leek confit with romesco sauce and the artichokes with salt. Amazing flavors! For the main course we shared the veal cheek cannelloni. And to finish this flavor experience we had the chocolate and yuzu coulant with greek yogurt ice cream. It was just an incredible meal. If you can't get a reservation just go by, they might be able to accommodate you.

review_preview: Lovely atmosphere - small and cozy, was just like eating in someone's home.  This restaurant only allows 20 covers,  this certainly makes it feel like a special and intimate experience. We arrived for a 9.30 pm booking and rang the bell (the door hadn't been...
review_full: Lovely atmosphere - small and cozy, was just like eating in someone's home. This restaurant only allows 20 covers, this certainly makes it feel like a special and intimate experience. We arrived for a 9.30 pm booking and rang the bell (the door hadn't been opened yet) immediately we were greeted by the owner (one of two sisters) She was helpful and friendly and made us recommendations and translated things when we didn't understand. The food is not typically Madrid in style but from the Rioja region where both of the sisters are from. The food is home cooked and delicious. We didn't have room for pudding but I can say the starters and main meals were really, really tasty. The price is in the higher side of mid priced (we paid 100 euros for 2 drinks, 1 bottle of very good Rioja wine, 2 starters and 2 main meals) but I feel that you get what you pay for and more here so fir me that's good value for money. Definitely one to visit on your stay in Madrid and you can book online.

review_preview: I was lucky to go the Vinoteca Moratin the day that I arrived because there would be a table for one available the next day for lunch.   As the other reviews indicate, one must make reservations, the sooner the better.  Fortunately for me, my hostal...
review_full: I was lucky to go the Vinoteca Moratin the day that I arrived because there would be a table for one available the next day for lunch. As the other reviews indicate, one must make reservations, the sooner the better. Fortunately for me, my hostal was also on Moratin Street. I was able to secure a lunch reservation for the earliest seating: 2:30 p.m.  To dine at Vinoteca is a culinary experience. I used “culinary” rather than “gustatory” because the meal is as much an exploration of the process as of the enjoyment. The owner/chef is Marcos. He wore Nikes and a beard and mustache peppered with gray. Marco is proud of his restaurant and eager to share with his customers each intimate detail of preparation and presentation. A diner should be ready to accept his enthusiasm and join in the culinary discussion. Otherwise, one should seek a restaurant where the chef is mostly behind the scenes.  Marcos explained each dish starting with a complimentary amuse-guele of potatoes and paprika, quite simple quite tasty, along with a flute of Cygnus champagne. Then an artichoke dish cooked long and lowly slowly, served with sea salt and olive oil. Excellent. Next came a soft octopus entrée with a glass of La Fou tinto (I did not note the year.) Very good combination. There was another course which I failed to note, but I recall enjoying everything immensely, including the fragrance of the main course, hot fresh mushrooms over pureed potatoes. I wafted the fragrance into my nose. The mushroom dish tasted great. Unfortunately, half way through this mushroom dish I began to feel a little queasy. I doubt that the dish was anything but perfect because it tasted delicious. I probably was still experiencing jet lag.  With dessert and a glass (perhaps two, I don’t recall) of the tinto, my bill was only 34 euro including tip. Thirty-four euro for a meal in one of the top ten (TripAdvisor) restaurants in Madrid. What a bargain ! (Of course, I had to leave something extra, hoping that this offer would not offend the waiter who did his job extremely well.) The outside and inside of the Vinoteca Moratin are unprepossessing. There is no napery, except napkins. The tables and seats are bare wood, minimalist. The emphasis here is on the food and service. Make your reservations soon.

title_review: An unusual yet fantastic Experience with great food!
review_preview: I had read the other reviews on Tripadvisor and was looking for something different for an evening meal in Madrid with my wife, brother and sister-in-law. I was not disappointed! I was staying nearby at the Hotel Opera (see my seperate review) but having been...
review_full: I had read the other reviews on Tripadvisor and was looking for something different for an evening meal in Madrid with my wife, brother and sister-in-law. I was not disappointed! I was staying nearby at the Hotel Opera (see my seperate review) but having been to Madrid several times previously and experienced both good and bad, cheap and overpriced, meals in the Spanish capital wanted to look for something special for my wife's and my brother's first visit and in particular something memorable. The restaurant is located just of the Plaza Isobel II in a side street (Calle Union) opposite the south side of the Teatro Real. It looks nothing special from the outside (especially during the day when it mostly has its shutters down but does have a large hanging plant growing outside which makes it easy to spot, I went one night to have a look (as it doesn't open until 9 p.m.) and found it closed so had to wander around another day, saw the shutters half opened and rang on the doorbell. The restuarant is run by two sisters Isabel and Pilar. The very charming Isabel answered, explained that a booking was required as the restaurant only had seats for 20 people. Booked there and then and nervously we turned up as a group of 4 slightly early (8.50 p.m.). Isabel asked us to wait outside as the tables weren't quite ready but let us in a few minutes later. Wow! I can only describe the restaurant as being a bit like visiting someone's house (say your favourite aunty) who has laid out a few tables for a private dinner party with a few select guests. Isabel then swung into action providing an English language menu and between her pretty good English and my broken Spanish we started to have a conversation just as if we were at our favourite Aunty's house making small talk and discussing our travels etc etc. Brilliant fun and so welcoming. The menu is not huge but lots of interesting things (with specialities from the Rioja region of Spain from whence the sisters come) which are prepared in the kitchen by Isabel's sister Pilar. Little nibbles were provided to keep us going and we chose the house red which Isobel proudly showed bore the name of her (and her sister's) restuarant on the label. As is only right for two sisters from Rioja it was an exellent Rioja wine! Isabel was happy to let us order starters (and later puddings) to share which was just as well as the mains were very filling indeed and absolutely delicious! Pilar the chef came out afterwards and spoke to all the customers about their meals and like her sister was very chatty and welcoming. In summary, not the cheapest but very good value for money, food was superbly cooked and delicious but without doubt, for me, the absolute best thing about this restaurant is the feeling of exclusivity, being part of such a small group, the undivided individual attention shown by both Isabel and Pilar to their customers and the amazing homely surroundings. As I said previously, it was like being invited to a family dinner with the best food and the best wine and, (this is for you Isabel and Pilar), the best company.

title_review: Great ambience and service, good but unspectacular food and wine
review_preview: I suppose the headline sums it up for me. I was travelling along on business, and went there based on the TripAdvisor reviews. The decor, seating/table arrangements and atmosphere were perfect for what I wanted: a nice place to have dinner and a glass of...
review_full: I suppose the headline sums it up for me. I was travelling along on business, and went there based on the TripAdvisor reviews. The decor, seating/table arrangements and atmosphere were perfect for what I wanted: a nice place to have dinner and a glass of wine while reading my book. The service was great: prompt, knowledgeable and very warm and friendly from all three people I dealt with. The food was good, but I did feel a tad disappointed having expected perhaps too much after reading the reviews. While tasty it was fairly basic (I had a half-portion of polpo on mashed potatoes followed by the veal cannelloni and a Creme brûlée-style desert). All the food was tasty but lacked a spark of elegance or inspiration. I'd say a good 3 or low 4 out of five - not average in a bad way, just solidly decent but not more. I was offered two tasters of wine by the glass, which was a nice touch. One was a fairly boring mainstream number from a mainstream producer, the other a more interesting Tempranillo from Rivera del Duero. Very good for the price (€4) but nothing special. I suspect the ones not offered by the glass but only whole bottles will be the better ones, which is fine and to be expected. All of in all, perfectly good and I'd go back, but with expectations adjusted. It certainly was not my best meal in Madrid but it fit the bill for what I wanted. While my earlier lunch at Luzi Bombon (goat's leg and truffled potato puree) was very good indeed and better for the food alone, I would not have wanted to go there for dinner on my own with a book. For that Moratin Vinoteca was a very good choice.

title_review: Superb little find! Really happy we went here.
review_preview: During our 4 day city break to Madrid we used Tripadvisor to find some good places to go and eat and we were so pleased we went to Restaurante Morgana. A small but perfectly sweet little restaurant in the Chueca district (right near our accommodation),...
review_full: During our 4 day city break to Madrid we used Tripadvisor to find some good places to go and eat and we were so pleased we went to Restaurante Morgana.  A small but perfectly sweet little restaurant in the Chueca district (right near our accommodation), we were met by two extremely welcoming and polite waiters/owners. Our Spanish is limited but we were introduced to the menu in superb English and given the best introduction to the Galician-fusion menu/wine list.  The croquetas were excellent (so crisp, excellent flavour and filling) and the tomatoes/avocado were a delight. So unique and very much haute cuisine - but reasonably priced.  Main courses - moules in a sort of spicy Thai or laksa-inspured broth for myself (I don't eat red meat) so it was lovely to see options of fish/vegetarian on a Spanish menu. My partner had the special of the rump steak, with padron peppers and potato chips.  To finish we had a breaded pudding with sweet sauce and apple flavours..  All in all it was excellent: service, food, price and setting. We would definitely recommend for foodies or walk-ins alike.

Sadly we have no Spanish, but that was no issue for the wait staff who were incredibly welcoming and very helpful with suggestions of food and accompanying Spanish wines. The food was excellent - the best we had in a 2 week visit to Spain. The wine choices (all recommendations of the waiter) suited the food perfectly. This was a great meal, in a small, welcoming restaurant. Highly recommended (but do remember to reserve a table in advance).

review_preview: We decided to visit this place after all the great reviews and it was a great choice, as we had some of the most delicious meat we have ever tasted. If you are a meat and steak lover like me, then you will definitely love...
review_full: We decided to visit this place after all the great reviews and it was a great choice, as we had some of the most delicious meat we have ever tasted. If you are a meat and steak lover like me, then you will definitely love this place. We visited on a very busy Friday night, and we were lucky enough to be seated immediately.  The interior is quite big, the ambience and the whole vibe of the restaurant was great and the service was knowledgeable and attentive. We wanted to try the argentinian meat, so we had the Strip Steak (Lomo Bajo) and the Beef tenderloin (Solomillo), both medium rare. Both of them were great, really tender meat, high quality and they were cooked to perfection. They have a large selection of wines to choose from, and many of them are also available by the glass, which is convenient. Normal prices for a quality steakhouse (around 30 euros per person without wine), definitely one of the best Argentinian restaurants in Madrid! I will be back whenever I visit beautiful Madrid!

review_preview: From the street, this is the sort of place you could easily pass by. Don’t! It is quite small but well worth either booking or arriving at the start of their sessions.The food is Galician - based on the region in the north western...
review_full: From the street, this is the sort of place you could easily pass by.  Don’t! It is quite small but well worth either booking or arriving at the start of their sessions. The food is Galician - based on the region in the north western part of Spain. All the staff are from this region so work well as a team and there is the added advantage that a couple of them have worked in the UK, so have an excellent working knowledge of English.  The waiters are very helpful and happy to explain the ‘compact’ menu. There are a total of 7 starters and 6 main courses, and although some may feel this is limited, perhaps ‘a few done well’ is better than ‘a lot done badly’? I loved the tuna pastry dish I started with and my wife was equally happy with the tomatoes stuffed with apple and avocado. The baked hake was excellent as a main course. Deserts, only 2 to choose from but again I loved the Spanish take on Tiramasu. All in all, reasonable price, great ambiance and helpful waiters....and of course, great tasting food. Loved it!

title_review: Galician food with an exciting twist
review_preview: We booked this restaurant for dinner on Saturday night after seeing the fantastic reviews on trip advisor. It surpassed our expectations: exquisite food (the cheese and kim chee croquetas were my personal favourite, but the Galician steak and parsnip puree were also highlights), delicious wine,...
review_full: We booked this restaurant for dinner on Saturday night after seeing the fantastic reviews on trip advisor. It surpassed our expectations: exquisite food (the cheese and kim chee croquetas were my personal favourite, but the Galician steak and parsnip puree were also highlights), delicious wine, a lovely cosy setting and a very welcoming group of friends running the place. One of them speaks great English and was pleased to help the non Spanish speakers in the group. The menu is available in English too.  The only disappointment was that we didn't save room for pudding! We thoroughly enjoyed our evening there and I'll definitely be back next time I'm in Madrid.

title_review: Galician Fusion: It's In, Not Con
review_preview: When it comes to food, I'm wary of the word "fusion" because for me it also spells "not authentic." So to hedge my bet, I ordered two fusion dishes (Galician-style taco and pulpo with kimchi mashed potato) and one traditional dish (tuna empanada). Ironically, of...
review_full: When it comes to food, I'm wary of the word "fusion" because for me it also spells "not authentic." So to hedge my bet, I ordered two fusion dishes (Galician-style taco and pulpo with kimchi mashed potato) and one traditional dish (tuna empanada). Ironically, of the three dishes, the two fusion dishes turned out to be more successful - although good, I think the empanada would have been better if it was slightly warmed up. I liked the tender meat and mild cheese in the taco. I'm not sure if it was roughly grounded corn chips, but they added another layer of flavor and extra crunchiness to the taco. I was worried that the kimchi might overpower the octopus dish, but it did not - rather, it added a slight kick to the potato, which in turn complemented the mild octopus flavor. Definitely worth trying for those looking for something new but do not want to wander too far off. Overall, I can say that this restaurant's attempt to meld different traditions resulted in INfusion, not CONfusion of flavors. P. S. This restaurant welcomes half orders so take advantage of it. Also, be patient because there might be some pauses between the dishes.

review_preview: We came across Kueco after a really long stroll across Madrid. It was late (10.30 PM). We were cold and hungry and we wanted to have good food. I’m normally not too generous with rating food. I’m a pretty good chef myself and if I...
review_full: We came across Kueco after a really long stroll across Madrid. It was late (10.30 PM). We were cold and hungry and we wanted to have good food. I’m normally not too generous with rating food. I’m a pretty good chef myself and if I cannot replicate a dish, to me that means I came across a special restaurant. Literally, I didn't had such good food in a long time. The taste was so delicately, fresh and pure. We had really good wine with it. They recommend to take one dish of each course, which we didn't because it was late, but I would definitely do so when I have the change to come back. I would take my friends and family to this restaurant, but even if I'm in Madrid for business, I would take my colleagues here to have. I'm traveling to many places very often for work and this is defenitely a restaurant to impress your business relationships.

title_review: Food beyond delicious, service left a lot to be desired
review_preview: I went here with friends and believe me, the food is right up there in my list of top places to eat, so why not 5 stars? Service.... I love good service; to start with that was forthcoming, but, and it is a big but........
review_full: I went here with friends and believe me, the food is right up there in my list of top places to eat, so why not 5 stars? Service.... I love good service; to start with that was forthcoming, but, and it is a big but..... Suddenly, near the end of the meal, we were presented with the final bill... No, would you like coffee or a digestif? just here, pay up and get out. Not how I like to be treated when I am spending €80-100 per person. I am sure if you eat early enough you will get 5 star treatment, but be aware of what lies beneath. We like to eat late and get good service, for which there is always adequate reward. May well swerve this one in future, which is a shame.

review_preview: We had booked a table through The Fork and it did not say that you would only have the table for 2 hours, and 2 hours is way too little time to be seated, look at the menu, have a snack, a starter, a main,...
review_full: We had booked a table through The Fork and it did not say that you would only have the table for 2 hours, and 2 hours is way too little time to be seated, look at the menu, have a snack, a starter, a main, a dessert, coffee. The experience was really stressfull and the waiters seemed really stressed as well. The Fork did not say anything about that the tasting menu is only served for dinner (and their webpage does not either). Furthermore there was a cold breeze through the restaurant coming form the ventilation above the door, we were moved to another table which was better. We had some snacks which tasted really good, and then some starters that were tasty but tasted somewhat the same, the mains were mixed: the duck was really good, the iberain pork ok and the beef cheeks too spicy. The water had a slight taste of chemical, so we are not sure it was bottled water (but filtered). The waiters were friendly but really stressed and we constantly felt rushed to finish and the food came really fast and we did not have time for coffee and dessert. If the purpose is to give guests a gourmet experience 2 hours is simply not enough, so they should write on the webpage that its more for people who want a quick dinner (and only 2 courses is possible in 2 hours if you should not feel rushed). All in all the stress ruined the experience which is a shame cause they have some good interesting dishes on the menu.

review_preview: Had lunch at Kuoco at close to 3.30pm (made reservations at 2.30pm but was late, so had to wait till tables are available). Loved the hummus(?) that came with the bread, was so tasty (subsequently found out that bread is chargeable at 2EUR). Would recommend...
review_full: Had lunch at Kuoco at close to 3.30pm (made reservations at 2.30pm but was late, so had to wait till tables are available). Loved the hummus(?) that came with the bread, was so tasty (subsequently found out that bread is chargeable at 2EUR). Would recommend the crispy wonton as starter. As a Singaporean, the chilli crab croquette didn't really taste like what we have back home (their version is creamier and less spicy), so I wouldn't recommend it. Had the black noodles - with seared squid and crispy onions - this could do with less salt, but is a fusion dish done well - gravy was good and not too spicy. Finished off with a yoghurt dessert with matcha meringue(?) and figs - great end to a meal and I actually don't really eat figs but I polished the bowl. Not exactly cheap but had an enjoyable meal. There was a male staff who could speak English very well and had good recommendations.

The dessert consisted of two squares of something that reminded me of rice pudding, crème brulée. but the texture was rather fluffy, which made it not as heavy as you would think.  The atmosphere was relaxed and lively, and our waiter was very attentive. I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone who appreciates fine food!

title_review: A great way to explore spanish wines!
review_preview: Preface: I've been looking for a place to do wine tasting in Madrid. There are many wonderful wines in Spain that are hard if not impossible to find in the US. Past experience suggested that they are very good and very inexpensive. Angelita is a...
review_full: Preface: I've been looking for a place to do wine tasting in Madrid. There are many wonderful wines in Spain that are hard if not impossible to find in the US. Past experience suggested that they are very good and very inexpensive.  Angelita is a wine pairing delight. We were fortunate to be waited on by the sommelier - one of the brothers who run the joint.  We gave him some broad direction and he did the rest. We had a few plates to share, and importantly, a cheese selection. He brought wines to the table with a great presentation of origin etc. We got to taste before committing to half glasses. Only turned one down out of 5   Food was outstanding. Ratatouille is their signature dish, but I was delight by the grilled pork, which tasted like beef. Sesame desert also not to be missed.

title_review: Excellent food and wine linked with most helpful service.
review_preview: Angelita was one of the restaurants recommended by my hotel, and they were right in their positive assessment. I ate in the street level wine bar, not the basement American bar.I was most lucky to get a seat as the restaurant is generally booked...
review_full: Angelita was one of the restaurants recommended by my hotel, and they were right in their positive assessment. I ate in the street level wine bar, not the basement American bar. I was most lucky to get a seat as the restaurant is generally booked full with reservations. I was asked if I would sit at the bar and said yes. I ended up at a small raised table above the main seating area and a few feet from the actual bar. It allowed good views of food, activity, and satisfied people. The menu is a simple one page list with the expectation that orders are for two to split. My delightful server said that there were entrees that could be ordered as half and I took his advice on selections. I had four small plates, dessert, and two glasses of wine. All was good. My first course was a single fresh oyster. Then a very tasty organic ratatouille with added texture, egg and rosemary mayonnaise. Different and delicious. Oxtail cannelloni with wild mushrooms brought another pleasing flavor. Then came the amazing charcoal Iberian pork with sweet potato and "burned" eggplant. The pork was tender and had a edge of crispness. The server said it is first grilled and then oven cooked. Dessert was porcini mushroom mousse with fruits and thyme crumble. It was a different taste and I expect that I will reserve judgment until I try it again. There was no rush, I was asked about my enjoyment level, and was treated with true concern. All in all, a real treat.

title_review: Great modern place for wine, cocktails, tapas or full meals
review_preview: I went here on a wine and tapas tour in Madrid; it seemed to be a favorite of our guide so I went back a few days later with friends. There is a very good list of wines by the glass and all the food...
review_full: I went here on a wine and tapas tour in Madrid; it seemed to be a favorite of our guide so I went back a few days later with friends. There is a very good list of wines by the glass and all the food we tried was excellent. Especially memorable are the Iberian pork dishes--"secreto" --Tender and delicious; "solomillo", plus one other. The in-season tomatoes come from the owner's family garden. We shared other dishes as well, which were all excellent. They have a great cheese board as well. We didn't try any desserts. There is a cocktail bar in the downstairs. Very modern decor.

This space is much bigger than this location and is more suitable I think for sit down dinner and drinks as there no bar at this location.

review_preview: We were able to secure an early reservation at this popular Argentinian steakhouse near Calle de Prado.  The wine was well priced and available by the glass, the wait staff was well informed about the menu and the options, and the salads were excellent.  We...
review_full: We were able to secure an early reservation at this popular Argentinian steakhouse near Calle de Prado. The wine was well priced and available by the glass, the wait staff was well informed about the menu and the options, and the salads were excellent. We had tuna tartare which was also excellent and a good sirloin steak. The only negative was that I asked for the steak to be cooked "Chicago-style", charred outside and rare inside. The staff assured me that they were fully familiar with this cooking method. However, when it arrived, the steak was neither charred nor rare...(it was nicely grilled and medium rare). Not anywhere near enough to send back, but this is not a cheap dining option in Madrid and so I offer this as a constructive suggestion to the kitchen.

I'm sure next years visit will include another visit to la Cabana. Well done guys on doing a great job

review_full: We celebrated my birthday here during our first day in Madrid. Started with a chorizo and a blood sausage, both were delicious. Followed that with a salad (tomato, rocket, corn and black olives). Then the main player, a rib eye for me and a filet mignon for my wife,wurg a side a fries with parsley and Parmigian. Great flavors, tender, juicy, just tight. My wife's filet did not require a knife to cut a piece try, I cut it with my fork! Finished it with my favorite (having been born in Buenos Aires), Panqueques con Dulce de Leche, made the night! A nice Malbec and it could not be better. Total bill was 116€, but worth it!

review_preview: Booked this restaurant which was quite difficult to find due to all the road works. THe taxi had to drop us off at the top of the street as he could not get down to it.We did not book as it was a Monday...
review_full: Booked this restaurant which was quite difficult to find due to all the road works. THe taxi had to drop us off at the top of the street as he could not get down to it. We did not book as it was a Monday night but it was not busy at the time of our arrival. However after 9,30pm it filled up so if you want to eat late it would be best to book. We had two steaks one fillet and one plank both of which where cooked to perfection (pink) along with two baked potatoes and their house veg which had alot of oive oil on it. It is Spain after all. The steaks required no seasoning whatsoever and melted in your mouth. No desserts. No coffees This is a good well run Argentinian Steak House and you get what it says in its name. When next back in Madrid and if wanting a steak I would recommend this place and go again. For this quality it was reasonably priced.

title_review: Surely one of the finest Steakhouses in Madrid.
review_preview: It was my great good fortune to have dinner here about 3 days ago.I was looking for a Restaurant fairly close to my hotel that I could walk to and not need to worry about how much wine I consumed. Grin.It's easily located...
review_full: It was my great good fortune to have dinner here about 3 days ago. I was looking for a Restaurant fairly close to my hotel that I could walk to and not need to worry about how much wine I consumed. Grin. It's easily located with Google Maps, well reviewed and bookings are simply made using the Google function. You can also just dial its number manually the old fashioned way. Unless you propose turning up at 11:15pm and hope to get a walk in table, I suggest you do make a booking as it is very busy. If you show up at a more normal 9pm without booking I suspect you will be disappointed. The person who answered the phone when I booked spoke perfect English. As the name of the Restaurant suggests, they are justifiably proud of their Argentine steak and accordingly this is what I ordered and what I recommend.  They do however have local steaks, excellent fish, pork and chicken dishes, so I think that any discerning diner will find something to his or her taste here. I hesitate to say that this is the best steak I have ever tasted. I can't recall however, a particular occasion when I have had a markedly better one. I can say that it was here that I found the finest tasting tomato I have ever had, as part of a delicious side salad.  As it was just quartered and in a simple salad, you might argue that little praise can be given to the Chef. Rather I would point out his/her product sourcing and attention to detail. I live in the UK and travel widely in Europe. I have experienced no tomatoes available in the UK which remotely compare in flavour.  Nor have I found any in France or any other place.  A little thing I know, but the Devil is in the detail, No ? The wine selection is as you'd expect and has choices for all wallets. I chose a dessert of Flambeed Crepes, similar to my all time favourite of Crepe Suzette, (but not with Oranges), this was also delicious and memorable. I tasted the dishes my companion chose and paid close attention to the dishes chosen by my neighbouring diners.  Everything I tasted was of a very high standard and all of the other dishes that I viewed I would be happy to order on another occasion. The decor and ambiance of the place is lovely and also memorable. The staff, I found, were friendly and efficient. To summarise, the whole evenings dining experience was a delight.

The menus were in English, and were, on the whole, well translated and the staff spoke English if that helps anyone.

review_full: Quite small and busy place in the middle of Chueca. Made our reservation quite late and were actually quite tired due to a late night the day before. The staff were very friendly, and it was a really nice atmosphere with people chatting with people at the neighboring tables.  Had a fantastic meal with tuna tataki, ceviche, steak tartar and iberica. Everything tasted as described by our waitress, and we were very happy during the whole evening. Four courses to share was more than enough, and the price were very affordable. We ended up paying 64 euro. I can recommend Kuoco360 for sure, and we are looking forward going there again next time we are in Madrid.  The mains in the Peruvian kitchen are quite heavy compared to the lighter, citric fish starters. The mains are basically a lot of meat, gravy and carbs. It is however good to keep in mind that the Peruvian kitchen actually is two different. I prefer the lighter kitchen with ceviche and fresh fish since gravy and meat is not my favorite. This does of course not impact the rating, just want to make sure that the place is right for you if you decide to go. Which I think you should.

review_preview: The restaurant lived up to its rating.  Went for the menu del dia lunch.  I had a delicious duck in a rich red wine sauce that was so good I asked for more bread to soak up the sauce.  My wife extolled about her black...
review_full: The restaurant lived up to its rating. Went for the menu del dia lunch. I had a delicious duck in a rich red wine sauce that was so good I asked for more bread to soak up the sauce. My wife extolled about her black noodle (linguini with black ink squid sauce and pieces of squid) entree as the best meal during this three week trip to Spain. The crispy wonton and crab croquette appetizers were just OK. We would order something else for appetizer the next time. The service is not equivalent to the food. The waiters were inattentive. I will certainly go again for the food when in Madrid. Recommend making reservations. Visa is accepted.

review_preview: We discovered this gem through a review in The Guardian and, based on the advice given, booked well in advance of our trip to Madrid. From the first email, the communication was great - prompt, friendly and welcoming. On arrival, the same qualities were evident...
review_full: We discovered this gem through a review in The Guardian and, based on the advice given, booked well in advance of our trip to Madrid. From the first email, the communication was great - prompt, friendly and welcoming. On arrival, the same qualities were evident and we were quickly seated and drinks ordered. There was something both informal and highly organised about the staff, and we were soon relaxed and thinking what to order. Marcos makes the menu redundant ! He took us through each dish with such detailed and passionate descriptions that it was hard not to ask for one of everything. When we suggested three starters (a family of three, one being a teenager), Marcos said he thought that might be too much food and suggested half portions of two dishes, and he was right to do so. We had leeks that were so sweet, sicculent and tender, and artichokes that dissolved in the mouth. The 'full' dish was octopus in a smoky paprika sauce. All three were delicious. The choice of mains was as difficult to make, but we plumped for chicken, cannelone and steak tartare. All perfectly cooked (or devised in the case of the steak) and flavoured. The wine list was very good, but this was an easier choice for us since we are currently impressed with Ribera del Duero wines, and the one we chose was a step up from our usual bottle. Time passed ever so quickly. The service was very attentive (our glasses remained empty for seconds only!) and the ambience was warm and lively but not intrusive, especially for such a small venue. The bill ? A very reasonable sum for this level of quality in a capital city on a Friday evening.

title_review: Great fusión cuisine with a worldly taste
review_preview: If you are high on food sharing, like good wines and have time to enjoy a good moment with friends, this is the place to go. Please make sure you  dont go on high volume times; we were four and arrived at 2:30 and left...
review_full: If you are high on food sharing, like good wines and have time to enjoy a good moment with friends, this is the place to go. The staff is very attentive and explain the qualities of each plate in a nice fashion. The dishes are very well presented and are super tasty. We ordered steak tartar, 7 potencias, ceviche, corvina and the Thai black noodles. For desert please ask for the Crema Catalana (With a citrus flavor) and the chocolate ice cream with shaved brownies. All in all a very nice experience.

review_preview: The concept behind Pizzateca is that Pizza meets library (biblioteca in Spanish).  Come in for one of their heavenly slices (personal favorites include the quattro fromagio, the pumpkin and panchetta, the marghareta, and the tutti funghi) and read one of their press' books which are...
review_full: The concept behind Pizzateca is that Pizza meets library (biblioteca in Spanish). Come in for one of their heavenly slices (personal favorites include the quattro fromagio, the pumpkin and panchetta, the marghareta, and the tutti funghi) and read one of their press' books which are on display. Yes that's right. They are also a small press who prints inexpensive paperbacks in Spanish and English. And they offer lunch specials including one where you get a book and a slice for about 3.50€ ($5). And these are large Neopolitan slices mind (the pizza chef is from Naples). Another special is two slices and a drink (and yes beer and wine count as do soda and water) for 6€ (about $8.40) The pizza is made with the freshest ingredients (literally, the chef is often in the produce market next door and I see him often when I am shopping). Stop in for a reasonable and delicious bite in the Barrio de Las Letras. Leave with your stomach full and a book or two!

title_review: A total disappointment in terms of business
review_preview: This is a story I would rather not tell...it really bothers me when a place with such good credentials fails in a not-so-understanding way...I was one day ago with a very good friend in Madrid, hanging around in a totally not occupied time slot...
review_full: This is a story I would rather not tell...it really bothers me when a place with such good credentials fails in a not-so-understanding way... I was one day ago with a very good friend in Madrid, hanging around in a totally not occupied time slot around the Museums (Prado/Thyssen-Bornemisza) quarter.l We searched for a nice Iberic wine place. And there's one, some friends mentioned to us. I'm going to be totally blunt: I suppose it's a nice place, it was wholeheartedly recommended to us. From the start I will admit that we had no prior reservation, and boy, did we learned a hard way lesson! We have very gently approached the staff around 8 PM and we have very decently accepted that all tables were booked and that the restaurant was not available for the evenings to come. We did understand, and we headed for a less in-the-bundle restaurant in the area. Heading back at around 11 PM in the evening, we passed along this place again. We really praised it, wanting a good evening to remember in this great city, a true European capital, Madrid!  We took a look inside and there were at least two tables where I and one remaining friend could be sitted in. With full fledged smiles we entered the place. It had more than an hour of opening hours, judging from its TripAdvisor advertising open hours. And this is where the spell was broken. Our evening in this ever-party city was ruined with a smile :). No, I'm not smiling! At a very early 11 PM, we were, frankly said, kicked out! Why? There's the funny part! Although there were admittedly free tables, at 11 PM, we were kicked out because, I quote: you haven't booked a table, and it would be unfair for the others to be accepted. We said: we did understand this earlier, at around 8 PM, when we walked away with no comments, as we had no reservations in place. But at 11 PM, with available places, why treat tourist so arrogantly? Why send us in such a discarding manner away? We even mentioned that there were no other opportunities in the near future and that we saw no reason in not being allowed to enjoy a relaxing night in the great Madrid, a city we so longed to visit. Our begging was so majestically ignored! Basically we were "invited" to walk away, regardless of our availability to order a full menu dinner (which was an excuse to be sent away, although the kitchen was long time closed!). I won't mention names, the employees have no doing in this humiliation. We were, according to "restaurant policy", invited to leave! We did mention complaining on TripAdvisor, and we received the most condescending smile you can image. Many things can be said about how we felt! But I will not have this review be driven by anger, as we have not chosen Madrid for this! We came here for the spirit of this great city! And we were grateful in seeing this all over the places we were so warmly invited in. Except this one. I've been in many places. Most of them not reviewed here.  But I have recently decided to share my experiences, so I will leave this here, for you to consider.

title_review: A fabulous meal in wonderful surroundings
review_preview: We had made sure to book by telephone well in advance and were so glad we did. Dozens of people were turned away as we ate, as the tables were all reserved. We were encouraged by the friendly and helpful owner to relax and enjoy...
review_full: We had made sure to book by telephone well in advance and were so glad we did. Dozens of people were turned away as we ate, as the tables were all reserved. We were encouraged by the friendly and helpful owner to relax and enjoy the evening, it's clearly not a place where they try to pack 'em in.  The food was delicious, the recommended accompanying wines were perfect, service was absolutely impeccable and we also enjoyed the art work on the wall, supplied by the owner's brother who owns a gallery in Madrid.  The price was so reasonable for food and a dining experience of this quality; make the effort to reserve and eat here, you won't regret it.

review_preview: I have been to many well regarded restaurants, Per Se in Manhattan  for example, but the thing that makes a restaurant stand out is the overall experience.  Marcos, owner of Moratin Vinoteca, provides just that... Not only is the food delicious,  but Marcos cares about...
review_full: I have been to many well regarded restaurants, Per Se in Manhattan for example, but the thing that makes a restaurant stand out is the overall experience. Marcos, owner of Moratin Vinoteca, provides just that... Not only is the food delicious, but Marcos cares about every bit of the dining experience. He explains each dish clearly (in both Spanish and English) and helps to choose the wines that will best suit your selected dishes as well as your palate. His genuine interest and kindness well surpasses that of the average restaurateur and made our dining experience one that we will never forget. I will encourage all of my friends to visit his restaurant and look forward to our next experience. Thank you for making our evening in Madrid so personal and so special!

title_review: Make reservations now!  It's worth it - charming location & staff and yummy, fresh food
review_preview: Small and charming restaurant with a focused, fresh menu of well prepared food.  The host/owner is so welcoming and so enthusiastic about his place and about the different menu options it was really wonderful to engage with him.  His positive attitude just rubbed off and...
review_full: Small and charming restaurant with a focused, fresh menu of well prepared food. The host/owner is so welcoming and so enthusiastic about his place and about the different menu options it was really wonderful to engage with him. His positive attitude just rubbed off and contributed to the overall experience. He made great recommendations both for food and for wine - getting us to try something new that we would not otherwise have experienced. All of our dishes - from starters through entre through dessert were each terrific in their own way. One thing I though was particularly great is that they mentioned the don't have multiple seatings so that nobody feels rushed - maybe that's more common in Madrid. Either way it's great to be able to take your time & linger and absorb the ambiance - which was nice, lively but not loud and a varied group of locals. We actually would have come back the next night (!) but sadly they didn't have any open tables. Nevertheless, the lovely owner gave us some recommendations nearby. I was traveling with family - and my companions are generally pretty picky and hard to please when it comes to restaurants - but in this case they too just loved the experience and the meal.

Try to go here.

review_preview: My wife and I had a wonderfully memorable dinner at the Morotín Vinoteca Bistrot.  I had made a reservation by email from home and I was glad that we did.  It is a small restaurant and was filled by the time we finished dinner (the...
review_full: My wife and I had a wonderfully memorable dinner at the Morotín Vinoteca Bistrot. I had made a reservation by email from home and I was glad that we did. It is a small restaurant and was filled by the time we finished dinner (the restaurant was empty when we arrived for dinner at 8 PM — late for us, apparently early for Madrileños). One of the reviews I had read said that the chef discusses the menu with each patron, which he did with us, and he also agreed to help me select a bottle of wine - based, of course, on the entrees we selected. He chose a wine from a bodega in Madrid, Bodega Marañones, which was fabulous. One great thing about the restaurant is that almost every wine in the wine list was priced from 20 to 30 Euros. The chef said that he created the wine list with price in mind, to showcase the extremely high quality of moderately priced wines. Judging by the wine that he suggested for us, he has succeeded! He took the time to speak with us for several minutes. He is clearly proud of his work and his restaurant and, as we found out, has every reason to be. It was a great choice and, without a doubt, our best dining experience during our ten-day trip to Madrid and Seville.  The menu had a good selection of appetizers, entrees, and desserts, and we had a tough time choosing among them. We started with a tomato salad, which consisted of a huge platter of simply delicious cut and peeled tomatoes, dressed only with olive oil and a little salt. This was a recommendation from the chef, who told us that the tomatoes were in season and probably would not be anywhere near as good in a week. They were fresh, juicy, and flavorful. We had a poached cod — incredibly good, not the salt cod that can be on offer in many Madrid restaurants. And two desserts, an apple tart and violet ice cream. The dishes were on the simpler side — our preference — but be assured that the chef was inventive and original without being flamboyant. The atmosphere was dark and subdued, a perfect place for a non-fussy romantic dinner.

title_review: Very good but not to everyone’s liking!
review_preview: Chose this restaurant on the basis of good Trip advisor reviews. We pre booked earlier in the day and on arrival were given a choice of available tables by the very self confident waitress that attended to us. She then went on to explain the...
review_full: Chose this restaurant on the basis of good Trip advisor reviews. We pre booked earlier in the day and on arrival were given a choice of available tables by the very self confident waitress that attended to us.  She then went on to explain the menu, discuss ‘degree’ of spiciness that we preferred. My preference was ‘not at all spicy’ and my wife chose ‘moderately’. All seemed OK, but when the starters arrived, my Ceviche Classico (tuna) was far too spicy for my enjoyment whilst my wife enjoyed her tataki (salmon). She then proceeded to finish my Ceviche which she said was more spicy than her starter! For the main course I had the chicken which a previous reviewer described as a ‘hoysin sauce’ and I am inclined to agree! My wife had the Sea bass and rice which she loved! My wife’s starter was whisked away from her as soon as she finished the last mouthful because her main course was ready and arrived at the table immediately. Hopefully the restaurant will look at their ‘timings’ as this made us feel rushed. Prices were reasonable and overall, the staff were very good. My wife would certainly rate this as a 5 stars but I would only give 3 so we’ve compromised and given a 4.

title_review: A delicious experience topped with perfect service
review_preview: The place is small but cute.  The service was excellent throughout, staff being very friendly and providing good suggestions and explanations to the dishes.We had:- fried wontons:  delicious bite-sized treat.  A must order.- beef tataki:  a bit of a fatty beef selection,...
review_full: The place is small but cute. The service was excellent throughout, staff being very friendly and providing good suggestions and explanations to the dishes. We had: - fried wontons: delicious bite-sized treat. A must order. - beef tataki: a bit of a fatty beef selection, but the pieces were easily chewable. The ponzu sauce added a nice touch of taste. - Duck: Absolutely delicious sauce / broth it is served in, but the duck was slightly overcooked. This is strange, considering it is served in a hot broth... one would think it would be undercooked for the people to finish the pieces to their liking in the broth. - Italian eclair for dessert: good variation of the classic, this one being a mash-up with a tiramisu cake. Interesting and tasty. We would definitely recommend this place.

title_review: Use of fresh, local food is so refreshing
review_preview: We went to Vinoteca Bistrot on our last night in Madrid, and it was a real treat. We were welcomed to the restaurant by the owner, who is very hands on throughout the meal; his philosophy of using fresh local food is refreshing and the...
review_full: We went to Vinoteca Bistrot on our last night in Madrid, and it was a real treat. We were welcomed to the restaurant by the owner, who is very hands on throughout the meal; his philosophy of using fresh local food is refreshing and the food has such flavour as a result. We were encouraged to share our food to maximize the items we could try - this was a wonderful approach. All the courses were excellent, especially the Veal Cheek Cannelloni (I can still taste how good it was!). We had several conversations with the owner throughout the evening about his philosophy of food procurement and preparation. It was a delightful evening and I would highly recommend it for the food, comfortable ambiance, and welcoming service. You'll need a reservation, many people were turned away who didn't have one.

title_review: Legend steaks, service a bit rough round the edges
review_preview: Have visited a number of times and the primary reason for returning is definitely the quality of the food - I am a carnivore of note and the steaks here have always been of a very high standard, and for what you get, at a...
review_full: Have visited a number of times and the primary reason for returning is definitely the quality of the food - I am a carnivore of note and the steaks here have always been of a very high standard, and for what you get, at a relatively decent price too. Service could do with a little more finesse though - friendly enough, but, for example our wine was brought to the table and opened, without showing us the bottle. Turned out it was not the Reserva per the menu, but a much younger wine - when questioned, I was told that "that is the wine and that is the price". When ordering the 2nd bottle the waitress did offer to bring us the other wine, of the two we were originally contemplating and both of which were called "Reservas" - this was clearly a Reserva, oh and the same price. So I felt their not showing us the bottle may have been because they knew they were not serving what they were selling - not great ! That said, it only applied to the wine, the rest was good and make no mistake, I will be back (just next time, insist to see the unopened wine first)

review_full: Every now and then it's nice to treat yourself and my favourite meal is a big slab of steak, a baked potato, and a nice bottle of wine. La Cabaña came up trumps with an excellent piece of 'Bife de lomo alto', a half bottle of Marques de Caceres, Flan con Dulce de leche (Creme brulée with toffee), a coffee and a small bottle of liqueur on the house. It's not cheap, but it's not fast food. The setting, service and quality were just what I wanted on this special day. I'll try and find another special day to go soon.

title_review: We were talking about the steaks the day after!
review_preview: Found La Cabana in Madrid actually April 2010 (but dates for this review only go back as far as June 2010).  Anyway, we ordered some fries and salad to go with it - don't bother.. the steak was SOoooooooo delicious you ruined the flavor by...
review_full: Found La Cabana in Madrid actually April 2010 (but dates for this review only go back as far as June 2010). Anyway, we ordered some fries and salad to go with it - don't bother.. the steak was SOoooooooo delicious you ruined the flavor by contaminating it with fries and salads. What can I say about this steak. I'm not a steak person, come from the UK, prefer chicken as steaks in the UK r like cardboard. However, this steak, madre mia! It melted in your mouth, was so tasty. It was however expensive: two steaks, fries and some salad to share, couple of beers cost 60 euros. Next day on the train to Toledo for the easter processions both of us had the same thought: that steak last night was so tasty wasn't it? A random thought by two people on a train about the steaks!!! Needless to say we went there the next night and paid another 60 Euros, this time we didn't touch the fries. Viva Argentina!
